boxTitle.jahia:value: Dynamic Nuclear Polarization and Hyperpolarization techniques (PHYS-735)

text.jahia:value:
Learning outcomes:

The course is intended for students who are working or wish to work in NMR, ESR or MRI. The main objectives are the following:

a) To introduce and define the sensitivity issues in magnetic resonance and the potential ways to tackle them
b) To give graduate students the conceptual tools to understand the principles of dynamic nuclear polarization and hyperpolarization techniques
c) To give an overview of the applications of dynamic nuclear polarization and hyperpolarization techniques in NMR and MRI

Content:

1. Review of important concepts in quantum mechanics (spin, density matrix,...)
2. Review of important concepts in thermodynamics (temperature, entropy,...)
3. Magnetic resonance: basic concepts in NMR and ESR
4. Spin interactions: dipolar, J- and hyperfine couplings
5. Spin relaxation: electron spin and nuclear spin relaxation mechanisms
6. Spin temperature: a thermodynamical description of spin systems
7. Sensitivity issues in magnetic resonance
8. Polarization transfer methods
9. Overhauser effect: DNP in liquid state
10. Solid effect and spin diffusion
11. Thermal mixing: thermodynamic model of DNP
12. Solid-state DNP techniques: concepts and hardware
13. Hyperpolarization methods: brute force, optical pumping, PHIP, dissolution DNP
14. Biomedical applications

A dissolution-DNP experiment is a three step process: first, the sample is polarized via DNP by microwave irradiation at low temperature and in a rather low magnetic field; second, the sample is dissolved in a hot solvent and transported into a high-resolution or an imager magnet by blowing high-pressure gas through a plastic tube; third, the solution is injected into the animal or the NMR tube and data acquisition is launched. The difficult hardware part is the low-temperature (1 K) cryostat required for the DNP process, the microwave part is relatively standard. Our collaborators from the Sample Environment and Polarised Targets group of the Paul Scherrer Institute provide the cryogenic know-how.

In the field of polarized targets a rather new DNP development is the use of photo-excited triplet states as source of electron polarization. Neither high fields nor low temperatures are required to achieve high proton polarizations, but the knowledge and understanding of these methods remains fragmentary and dispersed. Triplet-DNP is efficient even at relatively high-temperature ( ~ 100 K) and low microwave frequency (X-band) because the triplet polarization is determined by optical properties of the molecule and is therefore largely independent of temperature and magnetic field.

In a stricter sense, Dynamic Nuclear Polarisation refers to transfer of polarisation in solids from electron spins on spatially fixed paramagnetic centers to the nuclear spins. These methods were developed from 1957 onwards, mainly in Saclay and Berkeley, and had as motivation the development of nuclear-polarised targets for particle physics. The two principal processes for polarisation transfer are the "solid effect" and "thermal mixing". In both cases the ESR line is irradiated outside its center; for the solid effect even completely outside the line. The solid effect is a true, coherent, polarisation-transfer process, while thermal mixing is based on incoherent relaxation processes. In most polarised targets the sample material is a glassy frozen solution of stable radicals at concentrations of 10-20 mM; thermal mixing is expected to dominate, except perhaps for protons.

Dr. Patrick Hautle and Dr. Ben van den Brandt

Sample Environment and Polarised Targets group, Paul Scherrer Institute, Villigen

boxTitle.jahia:value: 2012 Molecular Frontiers Symposium on Emerging Technologies in Biomedicine in Singapore

text.jahia:value:
Lecture on “Probing Metabolism in vivo in Real Time”

Questions and answers session
Probing brain metabolism in vivo

Description
The most versatile hyperpolarization technique to increase the sensitivity of nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) is based on dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP). The main goal of the group is to develop hyperpolarization techniques for magnetic resonance spectroscopy and imaging in particular for biomedical applications.

The three main research axes of the group are the following:

Methodology in DNP, including DNP-related hardware developments, methods to increase the solid-state and the liquid-state nuclear spin polarization in molecules of interest, the design and implementation of new agents for hyperpolarizing biomolecules, and the conception and test of in vivo and in vitro protocols for biomedical applications.

Real-time uptake and metabolism, in particular in vivo studies in rodents using 13C- and 15N-labeled hyperpolarized biomolecules. Because metabolic fluxes are most often disrupted in pathological tissues, it is of great interest to be able to probe the biochemical transformations involved in the numerous metabolic reactions taking place in vivo. Experiments are performed on healthy animals and some diseases are studied in specific animal models, in particular in the area of oncology.

Molecular Imaging by MR imaging, a recent discipline combining molecular biology and in vivo imaging, aims at differentiating tissues based upon their metabolic and functional activity rather than structural and anatomic characteristics. Molecular imaging will greatly benefit from hyperpolarization techniques and experiments using long-T1 nuclear spins can provide essential information on the biodistribution, the uptake and the local environment of specific molecules.

This research is supported by the Swiss National Science Foundation (SNSF).

- Methodology in dynamic nuclear polarization to enhance nuclear magnetic resonance

- Low-temperature solid-state dynamic nuclear polarization

- Paramagnetic centers for dynamic nuclear polarization

- Hyperpolarized magnetic resonance imaging and spectroscopy for biomedical applications

- In vivo and in vitro real-time uptake and metabolic studies

- Molecular imaging by hyperpolarized MRI
